content.webTitle: Immigration Street review: ‘There are no real winners in this tale of Derby Road’

fields.headline: Immigration Street review: ‘There are no real winners in this tale of Derby Road’
fields.bodyText: Derby Road in Southampton is one of the most ethnically diverse streets in Britain. There are Latvians, Somalis, Lithuanians, Jamaicans, Hungarians, Iraqis, Poles, Russians – around 30 nationalities in all. Even a few Brits. In the last census, 17% of the area’s residents described themselves as white British. There also seem to be plenty of non-white British people, second- and third-generation immigrants, such as Rafique, who runs a shop, and whose parents came from Pakistan in the 1950s. To be honest, it’s hard to tell who lives on Derby Road – or Immigration Street, as Channel 4 is calling it – because most of them have fuzzed-out heads on television. They’re not keen to be there – on the telly, that is, not on Derby Road. Or Pixelation Street, as I’m calling it. There aren’t many consent forms being signed around here. That’s mainly because of Benefits Street and the hoo-ha that followed. This is made by the same company. One of the issues seems to be the title. (Is “immigration” really an offensive word, though? If so, is a lot of airport signage upsetting for some people?) A bigger problem for me is that they’re all being lumped together – refugees, recent arrivals from an expanded Europe and the descendants of people who came here over half a century ago. Also, you probably can’t get to the heart of a massive story such as this on one street, but I can see that television requires this kind of device. No one can argue that the subject isn’t justifiable – it’s the main story in Britain in the run up to this election. A valid exercise, then, so long as it’s done responsibly and sensitively – which, to be fair to Love Productions, it is. That seems to be the intention, anyway; the problem is that hardly anyone will play. And the people who do, who will be named and remain unfuzzed, are – with the exception of Jamaican Leroy – British. So it doesn’t work then, certainly not as the six-part series about immigration it was supposed to be. But, halfway through, Immigration Street turns into something else. What started as an unwillingness to take part turns into an attempt, by some, to stop the whole thing happening. The crew, plus the few participants, are intimidated, egged, threatened with worse. Someone is beaten up. It has changed from a film about immigration into a film about an attempt to make a film about immigration; a self-fuelling media story, with newspaper photographers taking pictures of the film crew, who turn their own lenses back at the snappers across the road. The filmers, now protected by security men, resort to interviewing themselves – it’s fair enough, I suppose, they’ve become the story. It’s like a snowball of hatred and mistrust and inward-looking irony rolling down Derby Road, gathering momentum, while from the sides a pixelated mob hurls eggs and abuse, and threatens to fire bullets. A so-called meeting between the community and the production company is a farce. The filmers are shouted down without being listened to; the politicians do what politicians do – say what they think most people in the room want them to say. The mob rules, Love Productions is run out of town and six episodes becomes one. A famous victory for the people over the media twats from London? No. If it’s a victory, it’s a hollow one. There are no real winners. Not Derby Road, certainly. And there’s further irony there, that what could have been a series that went beyond the headlines and the rhetoric and showed a multi- ethnic community in a sympathetic light ended up turning so ugly. It probably still says something about Britain today, but I’m not entirely sure what. On a less depressing note, Critical (Sky 1), Jed Mercurio’s new medical drama, is brilliant. We’re in the trauma unit of the futuristic City General hospital, where a badly mashed-up man is helicoptered in from a traffic accident/stabbing. And that’s it, we’re with the team – and literally inside the patient – as they try to stop him dying. In spite of the sci-fi set, Critical feels very real. It’s in real time, which certainly adds to the urgency. And the depiction of surgery is graphic (I couldn’t always look). But it’s also in the dynamics within the team, the power struggles and motivations. If Casualty and Holby are medical drama administered by drip, this is television defibrillation – charging, three, two, one, BOOM! – with a triple shot of adrenaline in the arm at the same time, while Jed pumps away at your chest. At the end, I felt I’d really been put through something, absolutely shattered, but also very much alive.
